coredata.dc:title: The three-body correlation spectral moments in depolarized interaction-induced light scattering of H2 at 297 K
coredata.dc:creator: Bafile, Ubaldo
Ulivi, Lorenzo
Zoppi, Marco
Barocchi, Fabrizio
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The three-body correlation spectral moments of depolarized interaction-induced light scattering have been measured in normal H2 at 297 K by means of an analysis of the density behaviour of the spectra between 10 and 300 cm−1. Comparison with classical calculation shows a major discrepancy for the second moment which is attributed to the anisotropic properties of the interacting molecules.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 138, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 7 August 1987 THE THREE-BODY CORRELATION SPECTRAL MOMENTS IN DEPOLARIZED INTERACTION-INDUCED LIGHT SCATTERING OF Hz AT 297 K Ubaldo BAFILE, Lorenzo ULIVI, Marco ZOPPI Istituto dt Elettronicd Quantistica, CNR, 50127 Florence. Italy and Fabrizio BAROCCHI Dipartimento di Fisica dell'Untversitd, 50125 Florence, Italy Received 1 May 1987; in final form 6 July 1987 The three-body correlation spectral moments of depolarized interaction-induced light scattering have been measured in normal H;at 297 Kby means of an analysis of the density behaviour of the spectra between 10 and 300 cm"'. Comparison with classical calculation shows a major discrepancy for the second moment which is attributed to the anisotropic properties of the interacting molecules. Depolarized interaction-induced light scattering (DILS) has been extensively used to derive information on the properties of interacting pairs of atoms and spherically symmetric molecules [ 1 ]. This is done experi- mentally by measuring the DILS spectra at low density in the gas phase and deriving the portion of the spectral intensity which depends quadratically on density. This ensures the connection of the measured spectra only with correlations of properties of isolated interacting pairs. When the density is slightly increased, it has been experimentally demonstrated that a contribution cubic with respect to density p appears in the DILS spectral intensity. Therefore this is now considered in a virial expansion of the form [2] *' N^(a)=NW(cD)p2+NW(al)p3. (1) Here N^((D) is the total number of photons scattered by the medium at the energy fico., and wavevector As per unit time, per unit solid angle, per unit u>=2K(vo-Vs) ("o, Vs are the incoming and scattered frequencies, respectively), and the polarization of the incoming radiation is along the direction of the scattering detection (depolarized geometry). Moreover in eq. (1) N^^w) p2 and N^^w) p3 represent the portion of the scattered photons which are related to the pair and triplet correlations, respectively. The spectral distribution N^^m) connected to the cubic behaviour with respect top has been measured and studied in argon and in several spherically symmetric molecular systems [4,5]; however, no results have been reported in diatomic molecules due to the great difficulty of measuring even pure N^^co) because of the pres- ence of allowed rotational spectra in the same frequency region. The case ofH; is of particular interest in this respect because the first rotational Raman line is at 354 cm""' and therefore pure translational spectra can be measured in principle in the first 300 cm~1 of the Rayleigh wing. Recently measurements of pure pair spectra have been reported at several temperatures [4-7] in normal hydrogen while the depolarization ratio for the pair spectrum of parahydrogen at 123 K has been measured *' The theoretical limitations of this approach have been already discussed by Poll [ 3 ]. 0 009-2614/87/$ 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) 559 Volume 138, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 7 August 1987 by LeDuffand Ouillon [8]. In this Letter we report the first measurement of the absolute zeroth and second moments of the three-body correlation spectrum, and the comparison with their classical theoretical values derived within the DID (dipole-induced-dipole) approximation for the induced pair polarizability and the spherical pair-interaction potential approximation. For the sake of simplicity we will refer to the same quan- tities we used in a previous paper [ 7 ], in particular to the double differential scattering cross section per unit volume F-' (d^n/d^dcy,)^-' N,(w)/no, (2) where no is the number of photons per unit time and unit area at the incoming frequency Vy, while V is the scattering volume. If the solid angle in which the scattered radiation is detected is small, as in our apparatus, and moreover we assume that only irreducible induced polarizabilities of pairs are important to describe the phenomenon, the scattering cross section per unit volume [9] for not too low frequency (u can be written as [2] ^/-l(d2(T||/d^d(Us)=^2 )||(12,(o)+/ 32)||(123,w), (3) where the pair depolarized spectrum 2?n(12, cu) and the three-body correlation depolarized spectrum Dn(123, u) are given by [2] <Xi A(12,^)=Awc^^J d<e ' </?,2(OJ?,2(0)P2((?,2)>^', (4) 00 00 D,(123,(y)=2?co c?^ J dte 'f <^(f)^(0) P^n))? +-hV2<^2(t)P^(0)P2(8 )>(o3)), (5) where fti^(t) is the pair polarizability anisotropy of the molecular pair i,j at time t, P-i(0,^) is the second Legendre polynomial ofcosffy, 6\,-i(t) is the angle of the intermolecular axis of pair 1,2 at time; relative to that at time t=0, and 023(0 is the angle of the intermolecular axis of pair 1,2 relative to that of pair 1,3 at time ;=0. More- over the averages < ^^, < >^3' are performed with respect to the "pure" pair and triplet distribution func- tions, i.e. the equilibrium distribution of isolated pairs and triplets, respectively, while < >i2' is performed with respect to the part of the pair distribution function which depends on the presence of a third particle. The even moments of the depolarized pair and of the three-body correlation spectra are defined as 00 Af^'= f dcrily2" ||(12,cd), --oo 00 M^= [ dwcD^D^n^w). (6) (7) Here we will primarily compare the experimental values we measured for the zeroth and second moments of the depolarized three-body correlation spectrum with theoretical ones and also report more precise values of Af^2' and M^ than the ones already published [7]. The theoretical expression for the moments on which the comparison is based can be derived from eqs. (7) and (5) and written as [2,9] 560 Volume 138, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 7 August 1987 o o- * * . + ' \ * 4 * + * * . t * i 4 0.0 100 200 FREQUENCY SHIFT (CM'1) Fig. 1. Three typical DILS spectra of normal hydrogen at 297 K. The measured intensities have been divided by the correspond- ing density and are given in arbitrary units on a logarithmic scale and are self consistent. The spectra are relative to the pressures: 40 bar (diamonds), 60 bar (triangles), and 100 bar (dots). (8) --^m^) o }+%{(^)(^)Y^e' +8v^((^)f^)^o(023)[ 1-^^0(023)]) \\a't2 / Vl3 / / 0 +^ ((^)f^) [4^ Y30(023)+2^7,0(023)]) 1, 3 \Vl2 / Vl3 / / oJ (9) where /y is the distance between the center of mass of molecules ; and j, ks is the Boltzmann constant, T the thermodynamic temperature, p. the reduced mass of the pair and 10(813) is the zeroth component of the /th spherical harmonics of 023(0 at time t=0. Moreover the averages < >o and < >i are performed with respect to the distribution function of isolated triplets and to the first density correction of the pair distribution func- tion respectively. We have derived experimental absolute values of M^, M^, M^, M^ at T=297 K from measurements of the depolarized spectrum of normal Hz between 10 and 300 cm-' as a function of density. Those spectra were measured at nine different densities between p= 17.8 and p= 129 amagat (1 amagat ofH^ corresponds to 2.6852 x 10~5 molecules/A3). The apparatus is the same as that described in a preceding paper [10] except for the photomultiplier we used to detect the spectral intensity. The new photomultiplier is a Varian VPM-164S cooled to T= - 40 C which has a dark noise counting rate of 0.7 counts/s together with an increased quantum efficiency with respect to our previous apparatus. This was important in order to maintain a good absolute precision while the total detection time for a single spectrum was reduced by a factor w2.5, which demonstrated crucial for this experiment on the very weak H, scatterer. With this new apparatus the average time for the detection of the translational spectrum of Hz and its absolute calibration was reduced to as 24 h. The spectral response of the new apparatus was again calibrated with a black-body standard source. The abso- 561 Volume 138, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 7 August 1987 lute calibration of all H; spectra was done with respect to the S(0) and S(l) rotational lines as an internal standard. Fig. 1 shows the Stokes side of three spectra Ny(v) at densities 34.93, 50.97 and 88.43 amagat. The zeroth and second moments of each experimental spectrum were then calculated by means of the integration on both Stokes and anti-Stokes sides extrapolating the spectra with exponential functions both at low and high frequencies. One third of the extrapolated contribution has been included in the error attributed to the exper- imental values of the moments. The contribution of the low-frequency extrapolation which affects primarily the zeroth moments ranges between 16% and 8% of their values, while the contribution of the high-frequency extrapolation, which affects primarily the second moment values, is typically 10% of their values. Figs. 2 and 3 show the behaviour of the zeroth moment My and second moment Af; of the experimental spectra as functions of density. A quadratic least-squares fit ofMo/p and M^/p allowed then the determination of the moments of the pair spectrum M^, M^ and of the three-body correlation spectra M^\ M^. The results are reported in table 1. For the case of the pairs, the present experimental result can be compared either with our previous experiment [ 7 ] or with the early one reported by Lallemand [12]. Taking into account the experimental errors, the three results are in substantial agreement. The interest of the present result lies in the improved precision. For the triplet intensity the only comparison can be with Lallemand's value [12], who, however, did not indicate any experimental error. Nevertheless, if we attribute to his value a relative error estimated as 2 or 3 times (at least) the error on the pair intensity, again we find satisfactory agreement between the two experiments. Table 1 also shows the comparison between experimental and theoretical values which were calculated by means of (8) and (9). The calculations were performed with the DID approximation for the induced pair anisotropy, i.e./?y=6a /^ with a value of 0:0 =0.827 A3 for the polarizabilityofHz at 5145 A, and the isotropic pair potential of McConville [ 11 ]. It is important to notice that our simple calculation does not take any account ^- IM 150 Fig. 2. Density behaviour of the DILS integrated intensity (zero moment). The ratio between the zero moment and the density (integrated intensity per molecule) (in arbitrary units) against the density. The full line is the best parabolic fit to the experi- mental points and its slope and curvature determine the pair and triplet contributions respectively. The pair contribution alone is represented by the dotted line. 150 Fig. 3. Density behaviour of the DILS second spectral moment. The ratio between the second moment and the density (second moment per molecule) (in arbitrary units) against the density. The full line is the best parabolic fit to the experimental points and its slope and curvature determine the pair and triplet contri- butions respectively. The pair contribution alone is represented by the dotted line. 562 Volume 138, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 7 August 1987 of the contribution of the permanent anisotropic polarizability of Hz, which may be of the order of 10% for the moments of the pair spectrum. Since this contribution is positive its inclusion in the calculation would improve the goodness of the comparison between the experimental and calculated values of M^ but would increase the discrepancy for M^ from ; 30% to as 40%. Therefore, from the comparison reported in table 1 we may conclude that as far as the pair spectrum is concerned normal Hz behaves very similarly to the rare gases [2] if an effective isotropic pair potential is used. In fact 90-95% of the zeroth moment is described by the long-range DID contribution while the discrepancy increases for the second moment suggesting, also in this case, the need for a short-range induced polarizability contribution for the accurate description of the full spec- trum. The calculations were performed in the framework of classical mechanics. However, the fifth line of the pair section of table 1 also shows the magnitude of quantum effects [13], which is negligible for the integrated intensity and amounts to 20% for the second moment. As far as the three-body correlation spectral moments are concerned table 1 shows the comparison between the experimental values and the calculation performed within the classical approximation. The M^ experi- mental value compares favorably with the calculation, even though not as well as for isotropic molecules [4]. Also in this case, similarly to M^, the remaining discrepancy of w20% could be attributed to the fact that the calculation neglects the contribution of the permanent anisotropy of Hz. A very different conclusion must be taken for M^\ which shows a dramatic discrepancy of a factor 4 with the calculation. We think that this should be attributed to the sensitivity of this quantity to the precise form of the interaction potential, as already noticed for spherical molecules [4]. Moreover M^ has several contributions of different spherical symme- tries, as is shown by eq. (9); these can greatly increase in the presence of an anisotropic contribution to the pair potential as well as in presence of a permanent polarizability anisotropy. Our conclusion for M^'1 is therefore that meaningful comparison between experiments and theoretical cal- culations for this quantity should take into account the anisotropic properties of Hz. This is not an easy task since the anisotropic pair potential of Hz is not well known and moreover the application ofeq. (9) in this case would be quite difficult. However if this calculation were possible then M^ could be a good quantity to study the anisotropic properties of Hz. As far as the three-body correlation spectral moments are concerned table 1 shows the comparison between the experimental values and the calculation performed within the classical approximation. The M^ experi- mental value compares favorably with the calculation, even though not as well as for isotropic molecules [4]. Also in this case, similarly to M^, the remaining discrepancy of w20% could be attributed to the fact that the calculation neglects the contribution of the permanent anisotropy of Hz. A very different conclusion must be taken for M^\ which shows a dramatic discrepancy of a factor 4 with the calculation. We think that this should be attributed to the sensitivity of this quantity to the precise form of the interaction potential, as already noticed for spherical molecules [4]. Moreover M^ has several contributions of different spherical symme- tries, as is shown by eq. (9); these can greatly increase in the presence of an anisotropic contribution to the pair potential as well as in presence of a permanent polarizability anisotropy. Our conclusion for M^'1 is therefore that meaningful comparison between experiments and theoretical cal- culations for this quantity should take into account the anisotropic properties of Hz. This is not an easy task since the anisotropic pair potential of Hz is not well known and moreover the application ofeq. (9) in this case would be quite difficult. However if this calculation were possible then M^ could be a good quantity to study the anisotropic properties of Hz. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The three-body correlation spectral moments of depolarized interaction-induced light scattering have been measured in normal H2 at 297 K by means of an analysis of the density behaviour of the spectra between 10 and 300 cm−1. Comparison with classical calculation shows a major discrepancy for the second moment which is attributed to the anisotropic properties of the interacting molecules.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Intermolecular spectroscopy and dynamical properties of dense systems
